title: What happens after a 14 day suspension?
body:
I just had a game where the entire lobby (both teams) flamed me for being useless. 

I was CSing in lane as Nasus and I refused to do a gank (I was at 10% health against Cait top). I ping him to fall back but my jungler goes in anyway and dies. My *whole* team proceeds to spam ping and talk shit to me. 

After the game, both teams called me useless.

"Oh, you lost lane to Cait?" - I won lane. I was ahead in CS and I took tower first.

"You made us lose" - I took the most towers, had the best K/D and I didn't throw early game.

"You needed jungler to win lane" My jungler hated me after the first death and stole my lane CS at every opportunity

"You sucked Nasus lol" - The enemy team

"Everyone report this idiot"

I've never been one to take shit from others so I told them off. 

5 minutes later I receive a message telling me that my account has been suspended and that I need to restart the client.  

I got a 14 day suspension for retaliating. 

The game: https://blitz.gg/lol/match/na1/Tried%20But%20Failed/3007475609

I'm not here to complain though. 

I just want to know at what risk am I to be perma-banned? Will the next chat-ban level offense be a perma-banned? 

If I'm at a high-risk for being banned, I'm just going to '/fullmute all' every game and play for fun. It's not worth getting tilted and losing my $500 account.

replies.body:
Your account is currently on thin ice. 

Though when you play plenty of clean games, you will drop back down to a clean slate. 

If your punishment was for disruptive gameplay,  it may take up to 9 months of  consistent clean play to get your account back to a clean slate.

Note that it takes a _very large_ number of games to get back down to the first tier of punishment from a 14-day ban. The game will also not inform you when you drop a punishment tier, and Riot has been purposefully ambiguous on how long it takes to drop a punishment tier.

Also note that it is based on games played, not time. That means that you have to be actively playing an account to drop it a punishment tier; you cannot passively have it drop.

Sort of like Game of Thrones - you win or you die.

Except here it's, "You shut up and stop fucking typing after your 14-day suspension or you lose your account."

I have a hypothesis that permabans are actually counterproductive, and increase toxicity in the game more than they reduce it. I suspect the vast majority of players who are permabanned will create a new account and keep playing. This means that they are now playing on a low level account at the start of that account, and so are playing with a number of new players. You now have the players judged to be the game's most toxic at far higher concentration than in the general population, in a situation in which their resentment over being permabanned likely makes them even more toxic, playing with new players. This results in the new players learning to be toxic right from the start, and perhaps even viewing that as behavior accepted by the community.

I do think a lot of them are probably queued with an experienced friend. But that's still new players playing with these recently permabanned players.

As for what to do instead of permabanning, I'm not sure. Could be repeated 14-day bans, could escalate to a longer but non-permanent ban, maybe require more than a simple throwaway email address to create an account. I'm not sure.

I also don't think that it's simply permabanned players playing with new players that could increase toxicity. I think the permaban may create resentment in the permabanned player themselves, and they may be even more toxic on their subsequent accounts.

And I could entirely be wrong here. As I said, this is only a hypothesis. Riot has the data that would either support or refute this.

It's a shitty system. It doesn't stop toxicity because toxic people will do just that. So instead of evaluating each suspension manually, as they should do, they leave it to the automated system and let the cycle happen.

Once you get to permaban level, Riot has decided they no longer want you as a player. They don't want your money, they don't want to find ways to keep you playing. They don't want you to create a new account. New accounts are treated even stricter in terms of toxicity and griefing behavior.

Do you think manual reviews, if they happened, will result in Riot employees deciding that the system banned people in error? Here's a hint - it really doesn't ban people in error. Your "context" doesn't matter, you "defending yourself" doesn't matter. They're not going to unban you just because some other asshole "started it." Your negative attitude spreads to the 8 other people in the game who just want to play the fucking game and not hear your shit.

A permaban is the same as a bartender trespassing you for starting shit constantly. You're disrupting his other patrons and his business. You've been shown the door and you're not welcome back.
